MR.  C.  V.  ROWE'S  RECORD  IN  SYSTEM  WORK 
DURING  1906: 

Entire  system  and  operative  plan  for  two  of  San  Francisco's 
largest  Department  Stores. 

Improvement  in  system  for  California  Lumber  and  Railroad 
Company,  with  mills,  electric  light  plant,  logging  camps,  stores,  etc. 

Entire  system  for  California  Lumber  Co.  and  sawing  plant. 

Stock  system  for  San  Francisco  Jewelry  Store. 

Entire  system  for  San  Francisco  lumber  broker. 

Entire  system  for  very  prominent  San  Francisco  stock  broker.       ^ 

Systems  for  Land  Company,  two  lumber  dealers.  Investment 
Company,  two  mining  companie-.,  Cemetery  Company,  Oil  Com- 
pany, etc.,  etc. 

General  and  cost  system  for  one  of  San  Francisco's  largest 
iron  foundries. 

Systems  for  two  express  companies.  ^ 

Principal  names  in  every  instance  furnished  for  reference  to       j^ 
bona  fide  respective  clients.  >

,,''*■> 


Springfield  Fire  and  Marine  Insorance  Company 

1849-1906 

ASSETS,  October  31,   1906 $6,514,533.38 

LIABILITIES— Unpaid  Losses $   248,111.66 

Reinsuraace  Reserve 3,293,218.71       3,541,330.37 

Surplus  to  Policy  Holders    $2,973,203.01 


RECORD    of   the   SPRINGFIELD  in  the  Settlement 
of  Claims  in  the  San  Francisco  Conflagration. 


PAID  UNDER  "DIRECT"  POLICIES  (December  1st)— 

Face  of  policies $1,443,955.15 

Salvage  (4%)    58,949.34    $1,385,005.81 

Paid  other  companies  reinsured  619,680.64 

Total  amount  paid 2,004,686.45 

Received      reinsurance       from 

other  companies 416,221.91 

Net  paid $1,588,464.54 

LOSSES  IN  COURSE  OF  ADJUSTMENT— 

Direct  PoUcies,  (1) $  2,000.00 

Reinsuring  other  companies 38,033.60 

$40,033,60 
Recoverable  from  companies  re- 
insuring Springfield  (estimated)  $16,968.76  23,064.84 

Aggregate  Losses $1,611,529.38 


The  I'atio  of  salvages  under  "  direct "  policies  ( 4% )  agrees  with  the  first  published 
estimates  made  by  President  Damon  on  his  visit  to  San  Francisco  early  in  June.  It  is  the 
source  of  the  greatest  satisfaction  to  us,  and  must  be  to  our  friends  and  agents,  that  the 
figures,  on  final  adjustment,  do  not  vary  materially  from  the  figures  given  by  the  Com- 
pany under  sworn  statements  to  tlie  Insurance  Commissioner  of  New  York,  as  of  June  30. 

Quoting  from  Manager  A.  J.  Harding  of  our  Western  (Chicago)  Department: 

"  The  Company,  at  the  outset,  promptly  published  the  full  amount  of  its  liabilities, 
without  attempting  to  paJiate  the  truth  by  an  over-statement  of  reinsurance  or  probable 
salvage. 

"  The  SPRINGFIELD  was  one  of  the  first  Companies  to  face  the  full  measure  of  its 
liabiUty,  and,  from  beginning  to  end,  it  has  not  taken  advantage  of  the  necessities  of  a 
single  loss  claimant  by  deducting  an  arbitrary  estimate  of  supposed  earthquake  damages." 

In  an  interview  with  the  reporter  of  the  San  Francisco  Call,  published  June  5th, 
President  Damon  said  : 

"Our  losses  in  San  Francisco  are  approximately  $1,676,455.  They  have  not  varied 
materially  from  the  first  report  sent  on  to  the  home  office,  when  we  thought,  for  a  while, 
that  the  greatest  damage  done  in  San  Francisco  was  by  the  earthquake.  We  are  pro- 
ceeding to  settle  our  losses  upon  practically  the  same  lines  that  we  have  followed  in  setthng 
fire  losses  in  the  past." 

PACIFIC    DEPARTMENT 

Office,  Kohl  Building,  cor.  California  and  Montgomery  Sts. 

San  Francisco,  Cal. 

GEO.  D.  DORNIN,  Manager 
GEO.  W.  DORNIN,  Asst.  Manager  JOHN  C.  DORNIN,  2nd  Asst.  Manager. 


San  Francisco,  Dec.  1,  1906. 
To  the  Clients  of  the 

Springfield  Fire  and  Marine  Insurance  Co. 

Gentlemen:  Fully  recognizing  the  close  relations  between  the  insured 
and  the  insurer,  we  take  especial  pleasure  in  handing  you,  with  this, 
an  exhibit  of  the  financial  condition  of  this  Company  at  the  close  of  1905. 

Organized  nearly  sixty  years  ago  (in  1849)  with  a  Cash  Capital  of 
$500,000,  it  has  had  its  full  share  in  the  great  conflagrations;  that  of 
Chicago,  in  October,  1871,  requiring  an  assessment  upon  its  stock-holders 
of  sixty- five  per  cent  (65  per  cent),  and  that  of  Boston,  in  November, 
1872,  requiring  thirty  per  cent  (30  per  cent),  the  calls  from  the  subsequent 
great  conflagrations  being  met  from  its  own  direct  resources  without 
impairment  of  Capital.  The  Baltimore,  Rochester,  and  Toronto  con- 
flagrations of  1904,  cost  the  Company  $512,480.00.  The  aggregate  of 
losses  paid  since  organization  being  nearly  $40,000,000.00. 

The  Springfield's  net  loss  in  the  San  Francisco  conflagration  was 
$1,611,529.38,  of  which  $1,588,464.54  has  been  paid. 

The  modest  income  of  the  earlier  years  has  steadily  increased,  year 
by  year,  until  it  has  reached  three  and  one-half  millions,  in  1905,  and 
its  Capital  has  advanced  from  $500,000  to  $2,000,000. 

The  Springfield,  after  settling  its  San  Francisco  losses,  carries  a  Reserve 
of  unearned  premiums  of  $3,293,218.71,  and  a  Net  Surplus,  as  regards 
policy-holders,  of  $2,973,203.01.  The  financial  management  of  the 
Company  is  shown  in  its  revenue  from  invested  funds  (Interests  and 
Rents),  being,  in  1905,  $221,832.20,  enabling  it  to  meet  its  dividends  to 
stock-holders  without  recourse  to  possible  profit  in  Underwriting. 

The  Springfield  has  always  taken  a  broad  and  liberal  view  in  its  deal- 
ings with  its  clients  and  agents,  without  losing  sight  of  the  underlying 
principles  and  practices  in  Fire  Underwriting.  To  this  is  largely  due 
the  excellent  position  the  Springfield  occupies  in  the  Insurance  world, 
and  especially  its  popularity  with  its  agents  in  the  local  field. 

Yours  very  truly, 


J.  A.  EICHORN  &BRO.

FAST  TRAINS,  STANDARD  AND  TOURIST  CARS, WITH  DINER 
LEAVE  FOR  THE  EAST    MORNING     NOON   AND    NIGHT 
LOCAL  TRAINS  TO   NEARBY  POINTS  AT  ALL  HOURS  OF  THE  DAY 

SOUTHERN    PACIFIC       ^ 


Heald's  Business  College,  Heald- Dixon  College, 

SAN  FRANCISCO.  OAKLAND. 

Heald's  Engineering  School,  Heald- Chesnut wood  College, 

SAN  FRANCISCO.  FRESNO. 

Heald's  Engineering  School,  Heald-Chesnutwood  College, 

STOCKTON.  SANTA  CRUZ. 

Heald's  Stockton  College, 

STOCKTON. 


These  Schools  prepare  pupils  thoroughly  for  commercial  pursuits  in 
all  lines;  also  for  practical  work  in  all  the  Engineering  professions.  The 
success  of  their  graduates  is  well  known  to  the  whole  community. 

HEALD'S  COLLEGE 

Has  become  a  household  word  all  over  the  Pacific  Coast,  as  it  has  stood  in 
the  front  rank  of  our  Educational  institutions  for  forty-three  years. 

PUPILS  CAN  ATTEND  EITHER  SCHOOL. 

Pupils  paying  at  one  school  can  attend  any  of  the  other  schools  if 
found  more  convenient.  All  the  schools  are  thoroughly  up  to  date  in 
their  methods. 

POSITIONS  FOR  GRADUATES. 

The  Heald  Colleges  have  always  made  it  a  point  to  take  care  of  its 
pupils  and  to  furnish  situations  to  all  worthy  graduates.  No  pains  will 
be  spared  in  the  future  to  find  employment  for  those  who  attend  any  of 
the  Associated  Colleges. 

HEALD'S  SCHOOLS  OF  ENGINEERING 

Give  pupils  a  scientific  and  practical  training  in  Mining  Engineering, 
Electrical  Engineering,  Civil  Engineering,  Steam  Engineering  and  Gas 
Engineering. 

RATES  OF  TUITION 

Are  as  low  as  is  consistent  with  first-class  instruction.  The  HEALD 
Schools  stand  for  quality,  and  any  one  patronizing  them  knows  he  will 
get  the  best  that  is  to  be  had  in  the  Educational  line.  This  is  why  their 
graduates  are  invariably  successful   in  their  callings. 

FULL  INFORMATION. 

Write  me  for  particulars  in  regard  to  any  of  the  Schools  or  any  of  the 
Departments  and  I  will  answer  personally. 

E.  P.  HEALD,  President, 

1451  Franklin  Street, 

San  Francisco,  Cal. 


J.  C.  WILSON,  ^^bSs'"" 

488  California  Street,  KohJ  Building  Telephone  Temporary  815

Sierra  :  Sonoma  :  Ventura 

The  New  Twin-Screw  Steamships 


^ 


)    lllLE?^NIE  STEAMSHIPGQM.P/Ctt^  (j 


Direct  Mail  Service 

WITHOUT   CHANGE 

Between  SAN  FRANCISCO,  HONOLULU,  SAMOA,  AUCKLAND 
SYDNEY,  SAN  FRANCISCO  and  TAHITI 

Under  Contract  with  Postmasters-General  of  the  United  States,  Tahiti,  New  Zealand  and  New  South  Wales 

Three  twin-screw  steamers,  SIERRA,  SONOMA,  VENTURA,  6200  tons 
each,  perform  a  new  schedule,  sailing  every  twenty-one  days  from  San 
Francisco  to  Honolulu,  Samoa,  Auckland  and  Sydney. 

At  Samoa  steamer  for  Suva,  Fiji;  at  Auckland  with  steamers  for  New 
Zealand  Ports;  and  at  Sydney  with  railroad  and  steamer  for  Melbourne  and 
all  Australian  ports. 

Steamers  sail  three  times  a  month  to  Honolulu;  every  twenty-one  days, 
via  Honolulu  to  Samoa,  Auckland  and  Sydney;  and  every  thirty-six  days  to 
Papeete,  Tahiti. 


Oceanic  Steamship  Company 

J.  D.  SPRECKELS  &  BROS.  CO.,  General  Agents 
L.  F.  COCKROFT,      -      General  Passenger  Agent

Incorporated  April  12,  1859  Re-incorporated  August  30,  1864 

OFFICE,  COR.  MARKET,  McALLISTER  AND  JONES  STS., 
SAN    FRANCISCO,   CAL. 

The  objects  for  which  this  Association  is  formed  are,  that  by  its 
o]-)crations  the  depositor  thereof  may  be  able  to  find  a 

SECURE  AND  PROFITABLE  INVESTMENT  FOR  SMALL  SAVINGS 

And  borrowers  may  have  an  opportunity  of  obtaining  from  it  the 

use  of  a  moderate  capital,  on  skiving  good  and  sufficient 

security  for  tlie  use  of  the  same. 

OFFICERS 

^  President JAMES     R.     KELLY 

t  Secretary  and  Treasurer R.    M.    TOBIN 

Attorneys TOBIN     &     TOBIN 

Any  person  can  become  a  depositor  of  this  Society  on  subscribing 

to  the  By-Laws. 

Deposits  can  be  made   from  $5   up    to    $3,000.     Loans    made    on 

Security  of  Real  Estate  within  the  City  and  County.

to  undertake  all  proper  Detective  Business  entrusted  to  it  by  Railroads  or 
other  Corporations,  Banks,  Mercantile  Houses,  Attorneys,  or  Private  Indi- 
viduals.    It  does  not  operate  for  rewards  nor  engage  in  divorce  work.

CROCKER-LANGLEY    BISINESS  DIRECTORY. 


H  n 


Home  Industry      Keep  Your  Money  At   Home 

Western  Expanded  Metal  & 
Fireproofing  Company 

Factory    Not    Destroyed. 
Now  Running  Full  Time 


We  are  prepared  to  furnish  all  gauges  of  Expanded  Metal  and  all  sizes 
of  the  famous  Corrugated  Steel  Bars,  for  use  in  reinforced  concrete  construc- 
tion. We  have  made  arrangements  with  Eastern  Associates  and  Rolling 
Mills  to  furnish  all  above  materials,  enough  to  rebuild  San  Francisco.  Now 
booking  orders.     We  will  take  care  o    you. 

Factory,  730  Second  Street,  near  Townsend. 

The  Western  Expanded  Metal  &  Fireproofing  Company  came  out  of  the 
calamity  with  their  factory  and  shop  intact  and  are  now  engaged  in  doing 
considerable  repair  and  construction  work,  being  probably  the  first  one  to 
get  actually  at  work  on  the  Kohl  Building,  corner  of  California  and  Mont- 
gomery Streets,  whicii  building  was  originally  fire-proofed  by  this  Company, 
and  came  out  of  the  fire  in  better  condition  than  any  other  building  in  the 
fire  limits. 

The  Company's  factory  is  now  running  usual  time,  and  are  filling  large 
orders  for  Expanded  Metal,  and  are  prepared  to  furnish  Expanded  Metal  ol 
all  gauges  and  sizes,  as  well  as  the  famous  Corrugated  Steel  Bars,  for  which 
they  are  the  agents  on  the  Pacific  Coast,  for  fireproofing  purposes,  and  have 
arranged  with  their  Eastern  Associates  and  Rolling  Mills  to  take  care  of 
every  order  they  may  require  in  San  Francisco,  even  to  the  extent  of  the 
entire  rebuilding  of  this  city. 

The  buildings  fireproofed  by  this  Company,  like  the  Fairmont  Hotel,  the 
Kohl  Building,  the  Monadnock,  the  Newman  &  Levinson,  California  Wine 
Association  Building,  the  J.  A.  Folger  Warehouse,  Ferry  Building,  United 
States  Postoffice  and  Courthouse  Building,  7th  and  Mission  Streets,  Young 
Building,  corner  Spear  and  Market  Streets,  and  many  others  came  out  of 
the  fire  in  splendid  condition  and  show  the  value  of  their  construction.  As 
this  is  a  Home  Industry  builders  should  calculate  to  patronize  the  same 
before  sending  their  money  abroad. 


Western  Expanded  Metal  &  Fireproofing  Co. 

OFFICE  2265  CALIFORNIA  STREET 

Telephone  West  6478

LANE  HOSPITAL 

Corner  Clay  and  Webster  Streets, 

LANE  HOSPITAL  IS  A  DEPARTMENT  OF  COOPER  MEDICAL  COLLEGE, 
WITH  A  STAFF  OF  ATTENDING  PHYSICIANS  AND  SURGEONS  FROM 
THE  COLLEGE  FACULTY. 

ALL  REPUTABLE  PRACTITIONERS  ARE  ACCORDED  THE  PRIV- 
ILEGE OF  PLACING  THEIR  PATIENTS  IN  LANE  HOSPITAL  UNDER 
THEIR  TREATMENT  AND    RESPONSIBILITY. 

THE  HOSPITAL  CHARGES  ARE  $2.50  PER  DAY  IN  WARDS;  $3.50, 
$4.50   and   $5.00   PER    DAY    IN    PRIV-ATE  ROOMS.
